body_html:
@prb12 No, the latest Win GPU v1.0.1 release seems to be the issue. In the Jenkins build history the first wheel referring to v1.0.1 would be build 108, to be precise.

While I installed v1.0.1 from
https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/windows/gpu/tensorflow_gpu-1.0.1-cp35-cp35m-win_amd64.whl as per tensorflow installation guide, I am assuming that it should correspond to build 108 given the patch version numbers.

This version does exhibit the behavior previously fixed in by 105.

So this seems to be a recent regression of sorts. If need be, I could download the wheel for 108 directly from Jenkins and install to verify.

Hope this clarifies.

body:
@prb12 No, the latest Win GPU v1.0.1 release seems to be the issue. In the Jenkins build history the first wheel referring to v1.0.1 would be build 108, to be precise.

While I installed v1.0.1 from 
`https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/windows/gpu/tensorflow_gpu-1.0.1-cp35-cp35m-win_amd64.whl` as per tensorflow installation guide, I am assuming that it should correspond to build 108 given the patch version numbers.

This version does exhibit the behavior previously fixed in by 105.

So this seems to be a recent regression of sorts. If need be, I could download the wheel for 108 directly from Jenkins and install to verify.

Hope this clarifies.
